name: listen
content:
listen

verb
 
 
/ˈlɪsn/
 
/ˈlɪsn/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they listen
 
/ˈlɪsn/
 
/ˈlɪsn/
he / she / it listens
 
/ˈlɪsnz/
 
/ˈlɪsnz/
past simple listened
 
/ˈlɪsnd/
 
/ˈlɪsnd/
past participle listened
 
/ˈlɪsnd/
 
/ˈlɪsnd/
-ing form listening
 
/ˈlɪsnɪŋ/
 
/ˈlɪsnɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1.  
     [intransitive] to pay attention to somebody/something that you can hear
    • Listen! What's that noise? Can you hear it?
    • Sorry, I wasn't really listening.
    • He had been listening at the door.
    • listen to somebody/something to listen to music/the radio
    • to listen to a song/an album
    • I listened carefully to her story.
    • He was listening intently to what she was saying.
    • You haven’t been listening to a word I’ve said!
    You cannot ‘listen something’ (without ‘to’) I'm fond of listening to classical music. • I’m fond of listening classical music.
    Extra Examples
    • He was hardly listening, for he had too much on his mind.
    • I listened with half an ear to the conversation at the next table.
    • I was listening to the radio.
    • Lucy was only half listening to their conversation.
    • Now, listen very carefully to what she says.
    • Pym listened impassively until the woman had finished.
    • The guests were listening with great interest.
    • They listened to the announcement in silence.
    • We listened politely to his stories.
    Topics TV, radio and newsa1, Musica1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • actively
    • attentively
    • carefully
    • …
    verb + listen
    • will
    • would
    • not bother to
    • …
    preposition
    • for
    • to
    phrases
    • listen with one ear
    See full entry
  2.  
     [intransitive] (informal) used to tell somebody to take notice of what you are going to say
    • Listen, there's something I have to tell you.
  3.  
     [intransitive] to take notice of what somebody says to you so that you follow their advice or believe them
    • I tried to warn her, but she wouldn't listen.
    • listen to somebody/something None of this would have happened if you'd listened to me.
    • The government is willing to listen to any concerns that people have.
    • Why won't you listen to reason?
    Extra Examples
    • You need to listen to me!
    • He refused to listen to her explanation.
    • I didn't even bother to listen to his reply.

name: listen
content:
listen

noun
 
/ˈlɪsn/
 
/ˈlɪsn/
[usually singular]
jump to other results
  1. an act of listening
    • Have a listen to this.
    Word OriginOld English hlysnan ‘pay attention to’, of Germanic origin.
Check pronunciation: listen
matches: listen for something | listen out for something
relatives: listen for something | listen out for something
listen for something | listen out for something

name: listen in
content:
listen in

phrasal verb
jump to other results
listen in (on/to something)
  1. to listen to a conversation that you are not supposed to hear
    • You shouldn't listen in on other people's conversations.
    • They did not know that the police were secretly listening in.
  2. to listen to a radio broadcastTopics TV, radio and newsb1
See listen in in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: listen up
content:
listen up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
listen up
  1. (especially North American English, informal) used to tell people to listen carefully because you are going to say something important
    • OK everyone, listen up!
See listen up in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: listen for
content:
listen for

phrasal verb
jump to other results
listen for something | listen out for something
  1. to be prepared to hear a particular sound
    • Can you listen out for the doorbell?
    • We listened anxiously for the sound of footsteps.
See listen for in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

listen out for

name: Listen with Mother
content:
Listen with Mother

 
/ˌlɪsn wɪð ˈmʌðə(r)/
 
/ˌlɪsn wɪð ˈmʌðər/
jump to other results
  1. a BBC radio programme (1950-82) of songs, rhymes and stories for small children. The programme always began with these words: ‘Are you sitting comfortably? Then I'll begin.’
Check pronunciation: Listen with Mother
